content.title: KEY CHALLENGES IN THE GLOBAL SOUTH
content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 3

content.text: Lesson 3 Overview

For countries in the global South, the urgency of a just transition is evident. These nations not only confront the challenge of combating climate change but also must tackle entrenched socio-economic disparities, with poverty alleviation taking precedence. Despite the recognized importance of a just transition, many regions still struggle with a cursory understanding of this concept, even as governments seek to incorporate it into their national climate plans. In this lesson, we will delve into the specific challenges and opportunities that developing countries face in the context of the just energy transition. By examining these dynamics, we aim to shed light on strategies and initiatives that can facilitate a transition towards a more sustainable and equitable energy future for all.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: energy equity
concepts.body: Energy equity refers to the fair distribution of energy resources and services, ensuring that all individuals and communities have access to affordable, reliable, and clean energy, regardless of their socioeconomic status.

concepts.title: localized solutions
concepts.body: Localized solutions refer to strategies or approaches that are specifically designed to address environmental, social, or economic challenges within a particular community or region, taking into account its unique characteristics and needs.

content.text: Recurring obstacles in the Global South underscore the urgency of holistic just transition planning across all energy-intensive sectors—power generation, industry, agriculture, transport, and buildings. While challenges such as informal labor markets, fragmented land rights, and cultural ties to natural resources complicate progress, access to affordable finance stands as the foremost barrier. High capital costs for clean energy technologies, coupled with limited concessional funding and high borrowing rates, stifle the adoption of renewables in low-income countries. For instance, solar and wind projects in sub-Saharan Africa face financing costs up to seven times higher than in advanced economies, perpetuating reliance on cheaper, polluting alternatives (CATF, 2023). This “affordability gap” entrenches energy poverty, as 571 million people in Sub-Saharan African remain without electricity access despite abundant renewable potential.

Addressing these disparities requires gender-responsive capacity-building to empower marginalized groups, particularly women, who represent only 22% of the global energy workforce and face systemic barriers to STEM education and leadership roles. Initiatives must prioritize vocational training, data collection on gendered energy poverty, and inclusive stakeholder dialogues to ensure women benefit equitably from green job creation. Simultaneously, aligning climate and development goals demands scaling innovative financing mechanisms—such as blended finance and green bonds—to de-risk investments in decentralized solar microgrids, energy-efficient agriculture, and electric mobility. As Atteridge et al. (2022) note, synergizing these efforts can unlock co-benefits, like job creation in off-grid solar sectors, which employ over 370,000 people across Africa (World Bank, 2023).

Yet international climate finance remains skewed toward techno-centric projects, with less than 10% of funds targeting social justice outcomes. Bridging this gap necessitates reorienting financial flows to prioritize affordable, community-owned solutions—such as pay-as-you-go solar systems in rural Bangladesh or women-led clean cooking cooperatives in Kenya—while leveraging public funds to attract private capital (World Bank, 2023). For example, the Just Energy Transition Partnerships (JETPs) in South Africa and Indonesia aim to mobilize $46 billion by 2030, yet critics highlight insufficient focus on retraining fossil fuel workers or ensuring gender parity in renewable sectors (GIGA, 2024). By centering equity in finance and policy design, the Global South can navigate the dual imperatives of expanding energy access and achieving climate resilience, ensuring no community is left behind in the race to net-zero.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 3 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Regional and Community Dependence on Fossil Fuel Industries

content.text: The 21st-century shift toward sustainable energy is shaped by global climate goals and the urgent need to provide affordable energy access. While international agreements like the Paris Agreement highlight collective ambitions, progress remains uneven. For example, the United States temporarily withdrew from the agreement between 2017 and 2021 and initiated a second withdrawal in 2025 under renewed leadership, underscoring persistent gaps in global alignment. Central to this transition is balancing emissions reduction with equitable energy solutions, such as ending fossil fuel subsidies, expanding renewable energy, and improving efficiency. Innovations like green hydrogen are being considered for industries with high emissions, though their success depends on local needs, technological readiness, and sustained international cooperation—challenges amplified by shifting political priorities in key nations.

Fossil fuels dominate global primary energy supply, underpinning economic stability across key regions. In the Middle East, oil, natural gas, and coal account for 97% of primary energy consumption (2023), reflecting unparalleled reliance on hydrocarbons for power generation, industry, and export revenues. The Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS), including Russia and Kazakhstan, derives 88% of its primary energy from fossil fuels, predominantly natural gas (55%) and oil (28%). In the Asia-Pacific region, fossil fuels represent 83% of primary energy, with coal alone contributing 42%—the highest regional coal share globally—driven by demand in China, India, and Southeast Asia. Africa sources 83% of its primary energy from fossil fuels, though this masks sub-regional disparities: North Africa relies heavily on gas (65%), while Southern Africa depends on coal (72%) (Energy Institute, 2023) This enduring reliance underscores fossil fuels’ role in ensuring energy security and supporting livelihoods. It emphasizes the need for strategic planning to mitigate disruptions during the transition.

Region-specific strategies are critical to balancing climate action with socio-economic stability. Abrupt decarbonization in fossil fuel-dependent regions risks destabilizing labor markets and energy access, particularly in communities where extractive industries underpin livelihoods. For example, coal-reliant regions like Jharkhand (India) and Mpumalanga (South Africa) require targeted workforce retraining and investments in renewable industrial hubs to diversify economies while safeguarding jobs. Similarly, gas-dependent nations like Algeria and Iran must prioritize methane emissions reduction and integrate renewable energy into existing infrastructure to align with climate goals without compromising near-term energy security. The energy transition must be framed not as a wholesale phase-out of fossil fuels but as a shift in investment priorities. In the Global South, where energy demand is projected to grow significantly, the challenge lies in redirecting new investments toward cost-competitive clean energy solutions—particularly in power generation—while acknowledging that limited fossil fuel projects may still play a transitional role in meeting immediate energy needs. Organizations like the International Energy Agency (IEA) and African Development Bank (AfDB) recognize this duality, noting that strategic fossil fuel investments in regions like sub-Saharan Africa may be necessary to address energy poverty while renewables scale.

However, rapid shifts away from fossil fuels without adequate planning risk exacerbating unemployment, poverty, and social inequities. These challenges are amplified by overlapping crises, such as the COVID-19 pandemic and geopolitical conflicts, which strain economies and erode public trust. A just transition demands policies that prioritize economic resilience and social equity, such as inclusive job creation in renewable sectors and safeguards for vulnerable communities. The path forward requires tailored, context-sensitive approaches: In coal-dependent economies, phased transitions paired with renewable workforce development. In gas-exporting nations, modernizing infrastructure to reduce emissions while leveraging renewable energy potential. Across the Global South, scaling decentralized solar and wind projects to meet rising demand affordably, bypassing fossil lock-in. By aligning strategies with local realities and prioritizing clean energy investments where most viable, the global community can advance climate goals while fostering inclusive development—a balance central to UNDP’s mandate of equitable sustainability.
Economic Diversification and Workforce Transition in Asia-Pacific

In India, the state of Jharkhand offers a clear example of how governments are actively planning for a Just Transition. Heavily reliant on coal, Jharkhand's energy transition is seen as a chance to address longstanding social inequalities, including gender disparities, while building a resilient economy. The focus is on identifying new economic pathways and equipping the local workforce with skills suited for emerging industries. This involves formulating policy recommendations and frameworks for employment, ensuring that workers from the coal value chain can transition to decent jobs in the green economy.
Challenges of Fossil Fuel Dependency in the Caribbean

The Caribbean relies heavily on fossil fuels for electricity generation, leading to the highest electricity prices in the region, especially for net oil-importing countries. This issue worsens during hurricane season, when fuel scarcity drives prices even higher. Transitioning away from imported fossil fuels presents a significant challenge for the Caribbean. To address high electricity costs and vulnerability to supply chain disruptions, economic diversification and strong governance are essential for building more resilient economies capable of withstanding external shocks.
Scaling Renewable Energy in the Arab States

In the Arab States, despite being heavily dependent on natural gas and oil, there has been a rapid expansion in renewable energy capacities over the past decade. Countries such as Egypt, Jordan, and Morocco have made significant progress, with renewables now forming a growing share of the energy mix. However, natural gas remains the dominant source of electricity generation in the region. Achieving the ambitious renewable energy targets set for 2030 will require continued investment in technologies such as solar and wind, alongside strategic planning to ensure a just transition for workers and communities reliant on fossil fuels. National strategies are increasingly incorporating social protections to support vulnerable populations during this energy shift.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 3 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Expanding and upgrading energy transmission infrastructure

content.text: Part 2 Overview

As countries transition to cleaner energy sources, the ability to efficiently transmit and distribute renewable energy becomes increasingly crucial. Outdated transmission systems, designed primarily for centralized fossil fuel generation, are ill-equipped to handle the variable and decentralized nature of renewable energy, such as wind and solar power.
Modernizing energy transmission networks

Modernizing energy transmission networks is essential to integrate renewable energy sources while overcoming challenges such as grid bottlenecks, congestion, oversaturation, and constraint payments. In regions like Latin America, the Caribbean, and large parts of Africa, existing grids struggle with limited capacity and resilience, hindering the effective incorporation of renewable power generation. Upgrading these systems—and improving interconnections to facilitate electricity trade between neighboring countries—enhances energy security and increases the reliability of national power grids. Such investments are critical to ensuring that transmission networks can support diverse, distributed energy resources and withstand the impacts of climate change.
Addressing Energy Intensity in Eastern Europe and Central Asia

Eastern Europe and Central Asia face significant challenges in reducing carbon emissions due to outdated energy infrastructure and heavy reliance on fossil fuels. For instance, Kazakhstan, with the region’s highest emissions, exemplifies the pressing need for investment in modernizing energy systems and increasing renewable energy production. Countries and territories such as Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia (including the territory of Kosovo*), and other coal-dependent economies require substantial support in phasing out fossil fuels while ensuring a just and inclusive transition for their populations. In contrast, countries like Albania and Tajikistan are already making strides in renewable energy through hydropower, showcasing the diverse pathways to a lower-carbon future in the region. * References to Kosovo are made in accordance with United Nations Security Council Resolution 1244 (1999).
Smart grids and digital solutions

Digital solutions—including smart grids, intelligent metering systems, and virtual power plants—are transforming the energy sector within globally integrated markets. By adopting an interconnected approach that spans energy supply, demand, conversion, and transmission, energy systems can optimize resource allocation, balance grid loads, and respond swiftly to disruptions. This integrated perspective is crucial for building resilience and sustainability across diverse regions and economic sectors. Incorporating digital technologies into energy systems can greatly improve grid performance and resilience. Smart grids, intelligent metering systems, and real-time monitoring tools enable better management of electricity supply and demand, ensuring a more stable and efficient grid. For example, UNDP-supported projects in Africa, such as the development of a smart grid in Mauritius, showcase how advanced distribution management systems can automatically address power outages, optimize grid performance, and support the integration of renewable energy. These technologies not only enhance grid reliability but also facilitate adaptive solutions for off-grid communities, offering flexible, decentralized energy access.
Battery storage and system flexibility

Battery storage and system flexibility are critical for managing the variability of renewable energy generation. As renewable capacity increases, so does the need for reliable electricity storage—not only to support residential and commercial use but also to meet the essential energy demands of industry. Innovations in battery technology enable excess energy to be stored when generation exceeds demand, ensuring that power is available during periods of low renewable output or high consumption. Continued advancements in battery efficiency and cost reductions will further drive down project expenses, making renewable energy systems more accessible and reliable. By enhancing system flexibility, these technological improvements play a vital role in integrating renewable energy across all sectors, including industry, and in establishing a more resilient and sustainable energy future.

Integrating energy considerations into the broader framework of sustainable development, as outlined in the 2030 Agenda, offers a comprehensive approach to addressing both local and global challenges. An integrative approach reflects the complex and interconnected nature of the modern energy landscape and underscores the importance of collaborative efforts in shaping a sustainable energy future.
Regional integration and collaboration

Regional energy integration initiatives, like the Central American Electric Interconnection System (SIEPAC), demonstrate how cross-border transmission infrastructure can optimize energy resources and improve energy security. By connecting national grids, countries can share renewable energy resources, reducing their dependence on fossil fuels and gaining access to more cost-effective energy sources. However, for regional projects like SIEPAC to succeed, further investments are needed in both national and regional infrastructure to accommodate the growing share of variable renewable energy.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 3 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Land-related conflicts and water use considerations

content.text: Part 3 Overview

The large-scale deployment of renewable energy installations and the extraction of minerals for clean energy technologies each present distinct challenges for communities and ecosystems. Renewable energy projects, such as solar farms and wind installations, can sometimes overlook local land use and water resource management, potentially leading to community displacement or ecosystem disruption. Meanwhile, mineral mining for elements like lithium and cobalt often mirrors extractive practices of the fossil fuel era, raising serious concerns about environmental degradation and the infringement on the rights and livelihoods of people in the Global South.

In the urgency to combat climate change, some initiatives have prioritized the rapid rollout of these clean energy solutions without fully addressing their separate social and environmental implications. This oversight risks sparking widespread local resistance, as communities impacted by either renewable installations or mineral mining may suffer adverse consequences without reaping the promised benefits of energy access and sustainable development. A truly just energy transition must therefore recognize and address the unique challenges associated with both sectors, ensuring that the rights and well-being of all affected communities are safeguarded. The Indian Rewa Mega Solar project and lithium mining in Argentina exemplify the challenges associated with renewable energy land use. The Rewa project, intended to generate renewable energy for urban areas, has adversely affected rural communities, leading to loss of livelihoods and disruptions in agrarian lifestyles. Similarly, lithium mining in Argentina reflects extractivist approaches, prioritizing mineral extraction over other socio-economic opportunities. These practices, often described as "green energy colonialism," have sparked tensions and conflicts over land use, exacerbated by overlooked seasonal land-use patterns and unfulfilled promises of employment opportunities.

Additionally, the relationship between land use for renewables and water resources has raised concerns about increased stresses on available water sources and reduced access routes in both Indian and Argentinian contexts. Land rights in many developing countries, particularly in the Global South, are often not clearly defined, regulated, or recognized, leading to various challenges and inequities. For instance, in Colombia, approximately 52% of land tenure in rural areas was informal in 2019, contributing to inequitable land ownership distribution. Despite legal provisions granting women rights to land, social norms, and limited access to resources like finance often hinder their ability to exercise these rights effectively. Similarly, in Ghana, male farm ownership exceeds that of women by more than three times, especially for medium and large farms. Indonesia faces challenges regarding land ownership, particularly in forest and land management, due to a complex mix of traditional, customary, formal, and informal arrangements, leading to legal ambiguity and tenure insecurity, which in turn perpetuates land-related conflicts and affects community livelihoods. Indigenous communities, whose territories often overlap with areas designated for timber or palm oil concessions, face particular challenges due to the lack of recognition of their customary laws, leading to conflicts over land use.

A recent example highlighting the complexities of land rights in the context of resource extraction is the proposed lithium mining project in Serbia's Jadar Valley. In 2024, the Serbian government reinstated Rio Tinto's mining license for the $2.4 billion project, which had previously been revoked due to environmental concerns and public opposition. This decision sparked widespread protests, with thousands of citizens expressing fears over potential environmental destruction and the displacement of local communities (Financial Times, 2024). The insecurity of land tenure exacerbates existing socio-economic problems and inequalities during energy transitions. Unclear or lacking tenure can exclude individuals from support strategies, such as assistance for adaptation or low-carbon land management, and hinder access to interventions aimed at mitigating greenhouse gas emissions or enhancing resilience in the forestry sector. Moreover, unclear land tenure may affect eligibility for emergency programs and financial transfers intended to assist vulnerable groups during the transition. Therefore, the planning of climate-related interventions impacting land must carefully consider potential impacts on individuals, particularly women, who lack secure tenure.

Access to natural resources, such as forests, is a fundamental aspect of community identity and spirituality but is becoming more restricted due to large-scale economic activities. Forests serve not only as a source of livelihood but also as a core component of community identity and spirituality. Thus, when climate transitions relate to forest resource management and restrict access to forests, transition planners must engage with communities beyond offering alternative livelihood strategies. Psychological impacts and mental health problems are common in major socio-economic transitions, as documented in mining communities when mines close and communities are left with few livelihood options. Unfortunately, these issues are not always addressed effectively in the development of climate policy. In Colombia, where one third of the territory is managed under collective ownership by indigenous and Afro-Colombian communities, their involvement as stakeholders in discussions about land-use change and deforestation is crucial but often overlooked. Engaging with these communities in dialogue is essential for establishing and achieving the country's NDC goals effectively. This underscores the importance of addressing land-related conflicts and ensuring equitable access to resources and support programs during the energy transition process in developing countries.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 3 | Part 4
content.title: Part 4: Persistent poverty and energy access gaps

content.text: Persistent poverty in the Global South is closely linked to a lack of reliable and affordable energy access, particularly in Sub-Saharan Africa and Least Developed Countries (LDCs), creating a cycle of deprivation that marginalizes entire communities. Limited infrastructure, investment, socio-economic barriers, and high energy costs further hinder integration into sustainable energy systems, perpetuating energy poverty and deepening inequalities. Climate change intensifies these challenges, threatening economic and social progress and demanding innovative adaptation across sectors like food, water, energy, and industry. Addressing climate change offers a unique opportunity to mitigate poverty and narrow energy access gaps through a transformative shift towards a just energy system. While the transition to renewable energy sources may entail job displacements in sectors reliant on fossil fuels, it also presents the prospect of creating new green jobs that prioritize social inclusion and economic empowerment, particularly for vulnerable demographics like women and youth engaged in informal labor.

A just energy transition could enhance energy security by leveraging region-specific renewable potential, such as solar in the Sahel or hydropower in Southeast Asia. Distributed systems like solar microgrids provide critical off-grid solutions for remote communities, though they often complement centralized grids. This shift aligns with equitable distribution principles, ensuring energy solutions are tailored to local affordability and resource availability. Africa's wealth of energy and mineral resources serves as a cornerstone for sustainable development and poverty alleviation on the continent. By embracing renewable energy sources and adopting sustainable mining practices, African nations can forge climate-resilient economies while fostering social inclusion and generating employment opportunities. Almost all countries in Latin America and the Caribbean have submitted second-generation NDCs demonstrating heightened adaptation and mitigation ambitions. As a biodiversity superpower, the region carries tremendous potential to unlock transformative investment integrating water, biodiversity and the energy transition, among other sectors. Dialogues with local communities and Indigenous people are critical in establishing bottom-up solutions that also reduce inequality and poverty.

Drawing lessons from successful endeavors and emphasizing social inclusion in climate action plans, African countries can navigate the inherent trade-offs between economic progress and social welfare. However, unlocking Africa’s potential to leverage its abundant energy resources requires addressing structural barriers beyond policy gaps—including financing constraints, infrastructure deficits, and unequal access to technology. By fostering international partnerships, prioritizing decentralized renewable solutions, and strengthening institutional capacity, Africa can advance a sustainable and equitable future, breaking the cycle of poverty and energy disparity in the Global South.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 1 | Lesson 3 | Part 4 | Case Stury
content.title: Case Study: Sri Lanka

content.text: Case Study RBAP: Sustainable Biomass Energy - How can women upscale their fish drying business?

In Sri Lanka, biomass remains a critical component of the primary energy supply chain, accounting for amount 40% of the total energy consumption [1]. Rural households, in particular, heavily rely on firewood and other biomass resources for cooking, with urban households following suit to a lesser extent. Despite the prevalent use of firewood to meet a substantial portion of the rural population's energy demands, there is substantial untapped potential for further leveraging biomass resources, particularly in providing thermal energy for the industrial sector [2] and small-scale household businesses in rural areas. To reduce the dependency on fuelwood, a renewable energy project called “Promoting Modern Sustainable Biomass Energy” conducted by the Ministry of Power and Renewable Energy together with the Sri Lanka Sustainable Energy Authority, and supported by the FAO and UNDP, focuses on improving biomass energy efficiency. A core component of the initiative in enhancing women’s skills and employment opportunities by providing access to modern biomass technologies that improve productivity and reduce environmental impact. [3].

In rural Sri Lanka, women are vital contributors to household income, often running small businesses that depend on biomass due to its affordability and accessibility. The Sustainable Biomass Energy project aims to provide energy services and programs throughout the island in the form of biomass plants that can be used for generating electricity, cooking and drying, focusing on women's skills development and employment opportunities. As part of this initiative, women have accessed cost-effective methods to enhance their businesses. They have adopted innovative biomass energy forms and modern technologies, leading to improved home enterprises and reduced energy costs. For example, in Tangalle, a major deep-sea fishing center where women are key players in the local dry fish industry, the Sustainable Biomass Energy Project introduced improved dryers to rural communities, which significantly benefited women entrepreneurs. A 40 KW flatbed dryer for nine women greatly enhanced production, productivity, and incomes. Working hours decreased from ten to four hours daily, while monthly production increased from 200 kgs to 800 kgs. After two years, the modern biomass dryer elevated the quality of the final product, leading to improved living standards for the participating women.

By providing year-round energy solutions, these modern biomass technologies also support income diversification. During the off-season, the dryers are used to dry other local agricultural products such as chilies, pepper, and cinnamon. This ensures that women continue to generate income even when fish production is low, creating greater financial stability and resilience. The transition to modern biomass fuels, such as briquettes or pellets, directly contributes to a more just energy transition. In countries like Sri Lanka, where biomass serves as a primary energy source, there is a critical need to enhance the use-efficiency of this resource. Conventional methods of biomass often inefficient and environmentally harmful, leading to high carbon emissions and significant health risks for women who are predominantly responsible for cooking and household energy management. Modern biomass fuels, on the other hand, offer a cleaner, more efficient alternative that reduces these negative impacts. The shift to modern biomass fuels and technologies not only lightens the physical burden on women by reducing the need for firewood collection but also enhances their economic empowerment by improving productivity and lowering energy costs. Modern technologies such as biomass ignition or drying can propel a more energy transition. This technology processes biomass into briquettes or pellets, which have better calorific value and emissions compared to directly burning biomass (such as firewood). This approach directly increases the efficiency of biomass utilization and reduces the negative environmental impacts associated with conventional methods. In the case of Tangalle, women using modern dryers have been able to produce higher-quality goods at a lower cost, making their businesses more competitive and sustainable. .

To build on the successes observed in Sri Lanka and foster broader gender equity in energy transitions, attention could be given to expanding access to modern biomass technologies in rural areas. Collaborative efforts between governments, local actors, and international stakeholders can prove particularly effective when focused on training and capacity-building initiatives that equip women with the skills to use modern biomass systems. In parallel, the design of future biomass energy initiatives may benefit from integrating gender-sensitive approaches that ensure women's meaningful participation in decision-making and project implementation. Creating an enabling environment for women-led businesses to access technologies can significantly strengthen their role in the energy sector. Mechanisms such as micro-financing or grants tailored to women entrepreneurs could further enable the adoption of these technologies, fostering economic resilience and business growth in a sustainable manner. The experience in Sri Lanka illustrates how the integration of modern biomass fuels and clean energy technologies can promote more inclusive transitions. By reducing the physical burden of labour, increasing productivity, and opening up new income opportunities, these technologies empower women to take on larger roles in local economies. In turn, they also contribute to environmental sustainability by reducing carbon emissions and pressure on non-renewable biomass resources.
References

[1] UNDP (2024). Biomass Phase 2. [2] Sri Lanka Sustainable Energy Authority (n.d). Biomass. [3] FAO (2018). From Impoverished to Empowered. Sri Lankan Women Adopt Modern Biomass Technologies. [4] IEA (2023). A Vision for Clean Cooking Access for All: Executive Summary. [5] Asia Cleanen Energy Forum (2023). State of Clean Cooking in Asia Pacific Region and The Value of Integrated Energy Access Planning.

content.title: KEY TAKEAWAYS
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Integrated Just Transition Frameworks are Essential for Equity and Resilience
takeaways.description: Developing countries in the Global South face a dual challenge: addressing climate change while tackling entrenched socio-economic disparities. A just energy transition must go beyond techno-economic solutions to include social, economic, and environmental justice.

takeaways.title: Economic Diversification and Workforce Reskilling are Critical for Fossil Fuel-Dependent Regions
takeaways.description: Regions heavily reliant on fossil fuels, such as coal-mining areas in India or oil-dependent economies in the Middle East, face significant economic and social risks during the energy transition. Proactive planning for economic diversification and workforce reskilling is essential to mitigate job losses and social upheaval.

takeaways.title: Land Rights and Resource Access Must be Central to Renewable Energy Deployment
takeaways.description: Large-scale renewable energy projects, while crucial for decarbonization, often replicate extractive practices, leading to land-related conflicts and displacement in the Global South. Ensuring secure land tenure, particularly for women and indigenous communities, is vital to preventing further marginalization.
